speaker: TIMON
text_entry: SCENE II. Athens. A room in Timon's house.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS, with two or three Servants

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Hear you, master steward, where's our master?

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Are we undone? cast off? nothing remaining?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Alack, my fellows, what should I say to you?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Let me be recorded by the righteous gods,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I am as poor as you.

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: Such a house broke!

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: So noble a master fall'n! All gone! and not

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: One friend to take his fortune by the arm,

speaker: First Servant
text_entry: And go along with him!

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: As we do turn our backs

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: From our companion thrown into his grave,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: So his familiars to his buried fortunes

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Slink all away, leave their false vows with him,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Like empty purses pick'd; and his poor self,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: A dedicated beggar to the air,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: With his disease of all-shunn'd poverty,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Walks, like contempt, alone. More of our fellows.

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Enter other Servants

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: All broken implements of a ruin'd house.

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Yet do our hearts wear Timon's livery;

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: That see I by our faces; we are fellows still,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Serving alike in sorrow: leak'd is our bark,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck,

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Hearing the surges threat: we must all part

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Into this sea of air.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Good fellows all,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: The latest of my wealth I'll share amongst you.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Wherever we shall meet, for Timon's sake,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Let's yet be fellows; let's shake our heads, and say,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: As 'twere a knell unto our master's fortunes,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: 'We have seen better days.' Let each take some;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Servants embrace, and part several ways

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Since riches point to misery and contempt?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Who would be so mock'd with glory? or to live

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But in a dream of friendship?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To have his pomp and all what state compounds

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But only painted, like his varnish'd friends?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Undone by goodness! Strange, unusual blood,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When man's worst sin is, he does too much good!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Who, then, dares to be half so kind again?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For bounty, that makes gods, does still mar men.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My dearest lord, bless'd, to be most accursed,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Rich, only to be wretched, thy great fortunes

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Of monstrous friends, nor has he with him to

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Supply his life, or that which can command it.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I'll follow and inquire him out:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I'll ever serve his mind with my best will;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Whilst I have gold, I'll be his steward still.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit
